headline: What Georgians say about abortion and Roe v. Wade, according to polls
author: Isaac Sabetai
sentences: The Atlanta Journal-Constitution regularly polls Georgia voters and asked about abortion when it was on the U.S. Supreme Court agenda and as state lawmakers were considering a bill to significantly curtail the procedure in 2019.
A federal court blocked a 2019 Georgia law that bans virtually all abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy, except in cases of rape and incest that are reported to authorities.
Brian Kemp signed a bill in 2019 that bans all abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy, except in cases of rape and incest that are reported to authorities.
Most Georgians oppose overturning Roe v. Wade but are more open to placing some restrictions on abortion, according to recent polling.
In January, 24% of registered voters said they wanted the Supreme Court to overturn the decision, with 68% opposed.
Before Kemp signed the bill into law, about 49% said they opposed it, with 45% indicating their support.
In January, 54% of voters opposed allowing the law to go into effect, compared with 38% supporting it.
While the extremes often are the loudest in the debate about abortion, most Georgians see gray area.
In 2019, 24% also said the decision should be overturned, with 70% saying it should remain.
A majority in 2019 did say the procedure should be legal in most or all cases.
The margin of error on both polls was between 3 and 4 percentage points.
Georgia voters were asked if they supported or opposed the measure.
Three years earlier, the numbers were tighter.
